bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to William H. Wranek, Jr., December 11, 1947

div1.p: Hench requests clippings pertaining to his speech, at the University of Virginia, to send to the Reeds and to others who have given him Reed material.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to William H. Wranek, Jr., December 11, 1947
div1.opener:
December 11, 1947
Mr. William Wranek, Jr.
University New Service
University of Virginia
Charlottesville, Virginia
My dear Mr. Wranek:
div1.p:
Such is the power of the press that one certainly has to be cir-
cumspect and tell the truth! After leaving Charlottesville, I visited various
friends in the East and Mrs. Hench and I were entertained one evening in
Washington at the home of Walter Reed's son. A day later we visited Walter
Reed's widow and daughter in Blue Ridge Summit, Pennsylvania. In Washington
we also ran across another old friend of the Reed family. Believe it or not,
every one of these people had already received newspaper clippings concerning
my talk in Charlottesville, and if I hadn't said the right thing, it would have
been just too bad. However, they were all pleased with the remarks. General
Reed's wife asked me to obtain for her three or four copies of both the
clippings. She wants to send them to her children and other relatives. My
brother sent me a couple of copies but I have already used these and I would
appreciate it greatly if you could get me perhaps four copies each of the
the Charlottesville papers of Friday afternoon, November 14 and Tuesday,
November 18, that I may send to these Reed relatives. Mrs. Blossom Reed had
a nice clipping from some Richmond paper. Would you, by any chance, have one
or two copies of that paper that I could have? If not, would you let me know
what paper it is in?

I have an ulterior motive in receiving these clippings. They demonstrate
to those who were kind enough to let me have their material that I am using it
as they might have wished; that I am telling the story with due credit to those
concerned and that I am appropriately using their memorabilia.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
